Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network Records TAM 581
19 Linear Feet in 19 record cartons
1983-1996 The Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network, formerly the Bronx Teen Pregnancy Network, was established in 1983. The Network functioned as a self-selected coalition of organizations, institutions, individuals. This collection includes materials related to the Network's activities and programs that provided education, support, and guidance to teenagers in the Bronx, particularly on the topics of pregnancy and sexually-transmitted diseases. There is also a substantial amount of material pertaining to fundraising. Materials are stored off-site and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Yvonne M. H. Cook on behalf of the Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network in 1996. The accession number associated with this collection is 2011.062.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. Materials are in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Historical/Biographical Note
The Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network, formerly the Bronx Teen Pregnancy Network, was established in February, 1983, as a result of the large number of teen pregnancies in the area. The Network functioned as a self-selected coalition of organizations, institutions, individuals, whose primary objectives were: the provision of information and referrals, identification of gaps in services, establishing a linkage system which would expedite appropriate and effective referrals and serve as a forum for resource sharing and joint planning and activities. The idea came from a group of social workers who decided to set up a Network in each of the five boroughs. The Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network was the last one to survive.
The mission of the Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network was to promote communication, networking, coalition-building and support among service providers and youth; and serve as a resource for the provision of education, cultural enrichment, research, technical assistance in support of service needs of young adults. Information and referrals, resource sharing, delivery and coordination of services, education, training, and advocacy are major goals of the Network. They had a quarterly newsletter that was tied to the information given at the Network meetings.
The Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network closed in January 1996 because of lack of funding.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network Records; TAM 581; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Scope and Content Note
This collection consists of the records of the Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network from its founding in 1983 to its closure in 1996. The largest portion of the collection relates to the organization's unceasing search for funds (contracts, grants, proposals, and related material). However, there is also significant coverage of the Network's activities and programs that provided education, support, and guidance to teenagers in the Bronx, particularly on the topics of pregnancy and sexually-transmitted diseases. The files of executive director Agnes Cooper Dennis are especially well-represented, as is the Better Bronx for Youth program.
Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. Born-digital materials have not been transferred and may not be available to researchers. Researchers may request access copies. To request that material be transferred, or if you are unsure if material has been transferred, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by the Bronx Teen Resource and Referral Network was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
